HBP Portal Styleguide

Using HBP Common's Stylesheet

Getting Started

If you use bower/grunt as a build system for your application you should use the SCSS version of HBP Common's stylesheet. Otherwise you can use the CSS compiled version but you will have to deal with more constraints and less customization.

SCSS Version

  • Add a dependency to angular-hbp-common in your project's bower.json file
  • Link to dist/scss/hbp-common.scss from you project's scss file with the @import command
  • Before the import assign the path to the angular-hbp-common module to the variable $hbp-common-asset-path

The last step is required for the build to find where to access the non-css assets provided by angular-hbp-common like fonts and images. To customize the common stylsheet you can override all variables defined in the dist/scss/hbp/_variables.scss.

CSS Version

If you don't use a build system or SASS you can use the compiled version of the common stylesheet that you will find under dist/hbp-common.css (or dist/hbp-common.min.css for the minimized version). This will however require that you make sure that the assets in dist/assets are accessible from the common css under the path ./assets/.

Developing for the HBP Common Stylesheet

CSS Guideline

This is a list of remarks about the do's and don't of writing css for the portal.

Vendor Prefixes

The portal build system takes care of injecting the correct vendor prefixes based on which version of the browsers you want to support. This mean that when writing your CSS you should use the standard version of rules. This also means that you don't need to use any mixins for that.

Supported Browser

The CSS you write should work on browers like specified on the page https://bbpteam.epfl.ch/project/spaces/display/BBPWFA/Web+Development

Naming Convention

All the classes defined by the application should be prefixed by hbp-, this will minimize the risk of collision with existing classes of third parties libraries. An exception for this is the redefinition of existing third parties classes (typically bootstrap's).

When you write classes that define a UI element namespace them with hbp-[ui element name]- and make sure this name space is not already used in the stylesheet.

Whenever possible the naming of classes should stick with the BEM methodology (http://bem.info/method/).

UX Guideline

Throughout the application there are some common UX paradigm that you should try to reuse in order to generate a consistent user experience and reduce the learning curve. If you feel this list is incomplete add a new one here.

Scrolling

When dealing with list that include scrollbars keep in mind that some browser don't show the scroll bar. This may obfuscate the fact that there are indeed more element in the list. To give a visual cue to the user try to make sure that the size of the scrolled area is done in a way so that the last visible element is partially hidden. That way the user know that she can scroll the list.

Semantic collors

When you need colors to convey meaning use the one defined in bootstrap (and customized by our css): default, primary, success, info, warning, danger.
